description: Originally a variant of (and hence a doublet of) differ; from Middle English differren (“to postpone”), from Old French differer, from Latin differō.

verbs.description: defer (third-person singular simple present defers, present participle deferring, simple past and past participle deferred)

entries.meaning: (especially more common, historically) to postpone induction into military service.

(American football) After winning the opening coin toss, to postpone until the start of the second half a team's choice of whether to kick off or receive (and to allow the opposing team to make this choice at the start of the first half).

description: From late Middle English differren (“to refer for judgement”), from Middle French déférer, from Latin dēferō.

verbs.description: defer (third-person singular simple present defers, present participle deferring, simple past and past participle deferred)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To submit to the opinion or desire of others in respect to their judgment or authority.
